1032  /** Get a pointer to the raw halide_buffer_t this wraps. */
1033  // @{
1034  halide_buffer_t *raw_buffer() {
1035  return &buf;
1036  }
1037 
1038  const halide_buffer_t *raw_buffer() const {
1039  return &buf;
1040  }
1041  // @}
1042 
1043  /** Provide a cast operator to halide_buffer_t *, so that
1044  * instances can be passed directly to Halide filters. */
1045  operator halide_buffer_t *() {
1046  return &buf;
1047  }
1048 
1049  /** Return a typed reference to this Buffer. Useful for converting
1050  * a reference to a Buffer<void> to a reference to, for example, a
1051  * Buffer<const uint8_t>, or converting a Buffer<T>& to Buffer<const T>&.
1052  * Does a runtime assert if the source buffer type is void. */
1053  template<typename T2, int D2 = D,
1054  typename = typename std::enable_if<(D2 <= D)>::type>
1055  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1056  Buffer<T2, D2> &
1057  as() & {
1058  Buffer<T2, D>::assert_can_convert_from(*this);
1059  return *((Buffer<T2, D2> *)this);
1060  }
1061 
1062  /** Return a const typed reference to this Buffer. Useful for
1063  * converting a conference reference to one Buffer type to a const
1064  * reference to another Buffer type. Does a runtime assert if the
1065  * source buffer type is void. */
1066  template<typename T2, int D2 = D,
1067  typename = typename std::enable_if<(D2 <= D)>::type>
1068  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE const Buffer<T2, D2> &as() const & {
1069  Buffer<T2, D>::assert_can_convert_from(*this);
1070  return *((const Buffer<T2, D2> *)this);
1071  }
1072 
1073  /** Returns this rval Buffer with a different type attached. Does
1074  * a dynamic type check if the source type is void. */
1075  template<typename T2, int D2 = D>
1076  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1077  Buffer<T2, D2>
1078  as() && {
1079  Buffer<T2, D2>::assert_can_convert_from(*this);
1080  return *((Buffer<T2, D2> *)this);
1081  }
1082 
1083  /** as_const() is syntactic sugar for .as<const T>(), to avoid the need
1084  * to recapitulate the type argument. */
1085  // @{
1086  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1087  Buffer<typename std::add_const<T>::type, D> &as_const() & {
1088  // Note that we can skip the assert_can_convert_from(), since T -> const T
1089  // conversion is always legal.
1090  return *((Buffer<typename std::add_const<T>::type> *)this);
1091  }
1092 
1093  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1094  const Buffer<typename std::add_const<T>::type, D> &as_const() const & {
1095  return *((const Buffer<typename std::add_const<T>::type> *)this);
1096  }
1097 
1098  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1099  Buffer<typename std::add_const<T>::type, D> as_const() && {
1100  return *((Buffer<typename std::add_const<T>::type> *)this);
1101  }
1102  // @}
1103 
1104  /** Conventional names for the first three dimensions. */
1105  // @{
1106  int width() const {
1107  return (dimensions() > 0) ? dim(0).extent() : 1;
1108  }
1109  int height() const {
1110  return (dimensions() > 1) ? dim(1).extent() : 1;
1111  }
1112  int channels() const {
1113  return (dimensions() > 2) ? dim(2).extent() : 1;
1114  }
1115  // @}
1116 
1117  /** Conventional names for the min and max value of each dimension */
1118  // @{
1119  int left() const {
1120  return dim(0).min();
1121  }
1122 
1123  int right() const {
1124  return dim(0).max();
1125  }
1126 
1127  int top() const {
1128  return dim(1).min();
1129  }
1130 
1131  int bottom() const {
1132  return dim(1).max();
1133  }
1134  // @}
1135 
1136  /** Make a new image which is a deep copy of this image. Use crop
1137  * or slice followed by copy to make a copy of only a portion of
1138  * the image. The new image uses the same memory layout as the
1139  * original, with holes compacted away. Note that the returned
1140  * Buffer is always of a non-const type T (ie:
1141  *
1142  * Buffer<const T>.copy() -> Buffer<T> rather than Buffer<const T>
1143  *
1144  * which is always safe, since we are making a deep copy. (The caller
1145  * can easily cast it back to Buffer<const T> if desired, which is
1146  * always safe and free.)
1147  */
1148  Buffer<not_const_T, D> copy(void *(*allocate_fn)(size_t) = nullptr,
1149  void (*deallocate_fn)(void *) = nullptr) const {
1150  Buffer<not_const_T, D> dst = Buffer<not_const_T, D>::make_with_shape_of(*this, allocate_fn, deallocate_fn);
1151  dst.copy_from(*this);
1152  return dst;
1153  }
1154 
1155  /** Like copy(), but the copy is created in interleaved memory layout
1156  * (vs. keeping the same memory layout as the original). Requires that 'this'
1157  * has exactly 3 dimensions.
1158  */
1159  Buffer<not_const_T, D> copy_to_interleaved(void *(*allocate_fn)(size_t) = nullptr,
1160  void (*deallocate_fn)(void *) = nullptr) const {
1161  assert(dimensions() == 3);
1162  Buffer<not_const_T, D> dst = Buffer<not_const_T, D>::make_interleaved(nullptr, width(), height(), channels());
1163  dst.set_min(min(0), min(1), min(2));
1164  dst.allocate(allocate_fn, deallocate_fn);
1165  dst.copy_from(*this);
1166  return dst;
1167  }
1168 
1169  /** Like copy(), but the copy is created in planar memory layout
1170  * (vs. keeping the same memory layout as the original).
1171  */
1172  Buffer<not_const_T, D> copy_to_planar(void *(*allocate_fn)(size_t) = nullptr,
1173  void (*deallocate_fn)(void *) = nullptr) const {
1174  std::vector<int> mins, extents;
1175  const int dims = dimensions();
1176  mins.reserve(dims);
1177  extents.reserve(dims);
1178  for (int d = 0; d < dims; ++d) {
1179  mins.push_back(dim(d).min());
1180  extents.push_back(dim(d).extent());
1181  }
1182  Buffer<not_const_T, D> dst = Buffer<not_const_T, D>(nullptr, extents);
1183  dst.set_min(mins);
1184  dst.allocate(allocate_fn, deallocate_fn);
1185  dst.copy_from(*this);
1186  return dst;
1187  }
1188 
1189  /** Make a copy of the Buffer which shares the underlying host and/or device
1190  * allocations as the existing Buffer. This is purely syntactic sugar for
1191  * cases where you have a const reference to a Buffer but need a temporary
1192  * non-const copy (e.g. to make a call into AOT-generated Halide code), and want a terse
1193  * inline way to create a temporary. \code
1194  * void call_my_func(const Buffer<const uint8_t>& input) {
1195  * my_func(input.alias(), output);
1196  * }\endcode
1197  */
1198  inline Buffer<T, D> alias() const {
1199  return *this;
1200  }
1201 
1202  /** Fill a Buffer with the values at the same coordinates in
1203  * another Buffer. Restricts itself to coordinates contained
1204  * within the intersection of the two buffers. If the two Buffers
1205  * are not in the same coordinate system, you will need to
1206  * translate the argument Buffer first. E.g. if you're blitting a
1207  * sprite onto a framebuffer, you'll want to translate the sprite
1208  * to the correct location first like so: \code
1209  * framebuffer.copy_from(sprite.translated({x, y})); \endcode
1210  */
1211  template<typename T2, int D2>
1212  void copy_from(const Buffer<T2, D2> &other) {
1213  static_assert(!std::is_const<T>::value, "Cannot call copy_from() on a Buffer<const T>");
1214  assert(!device_dirty() && "Cannot call Halide::Runtime::Buffer::copy_from on a device dirty destination.");
1215  assert(!other.device_dirty() && "Cannot call Halide::Runtime::Buffer::copy_from on a device dirty source.");
1216 
1217  Buffer<const T, D> src(other);
1218  Buffer<T, D> dst(*this);
1219 
1220  assert(src.dimensions() == dst.dimensions());
1221 
1222  // Trim the copy to the region in common
1223  for (int i = 0; i < dimensions(); i++) {
1224  int min_coord = std::max(dst.dim(i).min(), src.dim(i).min());
1225  int max_coord = std::min(dst.dim(i).max(), src.dim(i).max());
1226  if (max_coord < min_coord) {
1227  // The buffers do not overlap.
1228  return;
1229  }
1230  dst.crop(i, min_coord, max_coord - min_coord + 1);
1231  src.crop(i, min_coord, max_coord - min_coord + 1);
1232  }
1233 
1234  // If T is void, we need to do runtime dispatch to an
1235  // appropriately-typed lambda. We're copying, so we only care
1236  // about the element size. (If not, this should optimize away
1237  // into a static dispatch to the right-sized copy.)
1238  if (T_is_void ? (type().bytes() == 1) : (sizeof(not_void_T) == 1)) {
1239  using MemType = uint8_t;
1240  auto &typed_dst = (Buffer<MemType, D> &)dst;
1241  auto &typed_src = (Buffer<const MemType, D> &)src;
1242  typed_dst.for_each_value([&](MemType &dst, MemType src) { dst = src; }, typed_src);
1243  } else if (T_is_void ? (type().bytes() == 2) : (sizeof(not_void_T) == 2)) {
1244  using MemType = uint16_t;
1245  auto &typed_dst = (Buffer<MemType, D> &)dst;
1246  auto &typed_src = (Buffer<const MemType, D> &)src;
1247  typed_dst.for_each_value([&](MemType &dst, MemType src) { dst = src; }, typed_src);
1248  } else if (T_is_void ? (type().bytes() == 4) : (sizeof(not_void_T) == 4)) {
1249  using MemType = uint32_t;
1250  auto &typed_dst = (Buffer<MemType, D> &)dst;
1251  auto &typed_src = (Buffer<const MemType, D> &)src;
1252  typed_dst.for_each_value([&](MemType &dst, MemType src) { dst = src; }, typed_src);
1253  } else if (T_is_void ? (type().bytes() == 8) : (sizeof(not_void_T) == 8)) {
1254  using MemType = uint64_t;
1255  auto &typed_dst = (Buffer<MemType, D> &)dst;
1256  auto &typed_src = (Buffer<const MemType, D> &)src;
1257  typed_dst.for_each_value([&](MemType &dst, MemType src) { dst = src; }, typed_src);
1258  } else {
1259  assert(false && "type().bytes() must be 1, 2, 4, or 8");
1260  }
1261  set_host_dirty();
1262  }
1263 
1264  /** Make an image that refers to a sub-range of this image along
1265  * the given dimension. Asserts that the crop region is within
1266  * the existing bounds: you cannot "crop outwards", even if you know there
1267  * is valid Buffer storage (e.g. because you already cropped inwards). */
1268  Buffer<T, D> cropped(int d, int min, int extent) const {
1269  // Make a fresh copy of the underlying buffer (but not a fresh
1270  // copy of the allocation, if there is one).
1271  Buffer<T, D> im = *this;
1272 
1273  // This guarantees the prexisting device ref is dropped if the
1274  // device_crop call fails and maintains the buffer in a consistent
1275  // state.
1276  im.device_deallocate();
1277 
1278  im.crop_host(d, min, extent);
1279  if (buf.device_interface != nullptr) {
1280  complete_device_crop(im);
1281  }
1282  return im;
1283  }
1284 
1285  /** Crop an image in-place along the given dimension. This does
1286  * not move any data around in memory - it just changes the min
1287  * and extent of the given dimension. */
1288  void crop(int d, int min, int extent) {
1289  // An optimization for non-device buffers. For the device case,
1290  // a temp buffer is required, so reuse the not-in-place version.
1291  // TODO(zalman|abadams): Are nop crops common enough to special
1292  // case the device part of the if to do nothing?
1293  if (buf.device_interface != nullptr) {
1294  *this = cropped(d, min, extent);
1295  } else {
1296  crop_host(d, min, extent);
1297  }
1298  }
1299 
1300  /** Make an image that refers to a sub-rectangle of this image along
1301  * the first N dimensions. Asserts that the crop region is within
1302  * the existing bounds. The cropped image may drop any device handle
1303  * if the device_interface cannot accomplish the crop in-place. */
1304  Buffer<T, D> cropped(const std::vector<std::pair<int, int>> &rect) const {
1305  // Make a fresh copy of the underlying buffer (but not a fresh
1306  // copy of the allocation, if there is one).
1307  Buffer<T, D> im = *this;
1308 
1309  // This guarantees the prexisting device ref is dropped if the
1310  // device_crop call fails and maintains the buffer in a consistent
1311  // state.
1312  im.device_deallocate();
1313 
1314  im.crop_host(rect);
1315  if (buf.device_interface != nullptr) {
1316  complete_device_crop(im);
1317  }
1318  return im;
1319  }
1320 
1321  /** Crop an image in-place along the first N dimensions. This does
1322  * not move any data around in memory, nor does it free memory. It
1323  * just rewrites the min/extent of each dimension to refer to a
1324  * subregion of the same allocation. */
1325  void crop(const std::vector<std::pair<int, int>> &rect) {
1326  // An optimization for non-device buffers. For the device case,
1327  // a temp buffer is required, so reuse the not-in-place version.
1328  // TODO(zalman|abadams): Are nop crops common enough to special
1329  // case the device part of the if to do nothing?
1330  if (buf.device_interface != nullptr) {
1331  *this = cropped(rect);
1332  } else {
1333  crop_host(rect);
1334  }
1335  }
1336 
1337  /** Make an image which refers to the same data with using
1338  * translated coordinates in the given dimension. Positive values
1339  * move the image data to the right or down relative to the
1340  * coordinate system. Drops any device handle. */
1341  Buffer<T, D> translated(int d, int dx) const {
1342  Buffer<T, D> im = *this;
1343  im.translate(d, dx);
1344  return im;
1345  }
1346 
1347  /** Translate an image in-place along one dimension by changing
1348  * how it is indexed. Does not move any data around in memory. */
1349  void translate(int d, int delta) {
1350  assert(d >= 0 && d < this->dimensions());
1351  device_deallocate();
1352  buf.dim[d].min += delta;
1353  }
1354 
1355  /** Make an image which refers to the same data translated along
1356  * the first N dimensions. */
1357  Buffer<T, D> translated(const std::vector<int> &delta) const {
1358  Buffer<T, D> im = *this;
1359  im.translate(delta);
1360  return im;
1361  }
1362 
1363  /** Translate an image along the first N dimensions by changing
1364  * how it is indexed. Does not move any data around in memory. */
1365  void translate(const std::vector<int> &delta) {
1366  device_deallocate();
1367  assert(delta.size() <= static_cast<decltype(delta.size())>(std::numeric_limits<int>::max()));
1368  int limit = (int)delta.size();
1369  assert(limit <= dimensions());
1370  for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
1371  translate(i, delta[i]);
1372  }
1373  }
1374 
1375  /** Set the min coordinate of an image in the first N dimensions. */
1376  // @{
1377  void set_min(const std::vector<int> &mins) {
1378  assert(mins.size() <= static_cast<decltype(mins.size())>(dimensions()));
1379  device_deallocate();
1380  for (size_t i = 0; i < mins.size(); i++) {
1381  buf.dim[i].min = mins[i];
1382  }
1383  }
1384 
1385  template<typename... Args>
1386  void set_min(Args... args) {
1387  set_min(std::vector<int>{args...});
1388  }
1389  // @}
1390 
1391  /** Test if a given coordinate is within the bounds of an image. */
1392  // @{
1393  bool contains(const std::vector<int> &coords) const {
1394  assert(coords.size() <= static_cast<decltype(coords.size())>(dimensions()));
1395  for (size_t i = 0; i < coords.size(); i++) {
1396  if (coords[i] < dim((int)i).min() || coords[i] > dim((int)i).max()) {
1397  return false;
1398  }
1399  }
1400  return true;
1401  }
1402 
1403  template<typename... Args>
1404  bool contains(Args... args) const {
1405  return contains(std::vector<int>{args...});
1406  }
1407  // @}
1408 
1409  /** Make a buffer which refers to the same data in the same layout
1410  * using a swapped indexing order for the dimensions given. So
1411  * A = B.transposed(0, 1) means that A(i, j) == B(j, i), and more
1412  * strongly that A.address_of(i, j) == B.address_of(j, i). */
1413  Buffer<T, D> transposed(int d1, int d2) const {
1414  Buffer<T, D> im = *this;
1415  im.transpose(d1, d2);
1416  return im;
1417  }
1418 
1419  /** Transpose a buffer in-place by changing how it is indexed. For
1420  * example, transpose(0, 1) on a two-dimensional buffer means that
1421  * the value referred to by coordinates (i, j) is now reached at
1422  * the coordinates (j, i), and vice versa. This is done by
1423  * reordering the per-dimension metadata rather than by moving
1424  * data around in memory, so other views of the same memory will
1425  * not see the data as having been transposed. */
1426  void transpose(int d1, int d2) {
1427  assert(d1 >= 0 && d1 < this->dimensions());
1428  assert(d2 >= 0 && d2 < this->dimensions());
1429  std::swap(buf.dim[d1], buf.dim[d2]);
1430  }
1431 
1432  /** A generalized transpose: instead of swapping two dimensions,
1433  * pass a vector that lists each dimension index exactly once, in
1434  * the desired order. This does not move any data around in memory
1435  * - it just permutes how it is indexed. */
1436  void transpose(const std::vector<int> &order) {
1437  assert((int)order.size() == dimensions());
1438  if (dimensions() < 2) {
1439  // My, that was easy
1440  return;
1441  }
1442 
1443  std::vector<int> order_sorted = order;
1444  for (size_t i = 1; i < order_sorted.size(); i++) {
1445  for (size_t j = i; j > 0 && order_sorted[j - 1] > order_sorted[j]; j--) {
1446  std::swap(order_sorted[j], order_sorted[j - 1]);
1447  transpose(j, j - 1);
1448  }
1449  }
1450  }
1451 
1452  /** Make a buffer which refers to the same data in the same
1453  * layout using a different ordering of the dimensions. */
1454  Buffer<T, D> transposed(const std::vector<int> &order) const {
1455  Buffer<T, D> im = *this;
1456  im.transpose(order);
1457  return im;
1458  }
1459 
1460  /** Make a lower-dimensional buffer that refers to one slice of
1461  * this buffer. */
1462  Buffer<T, D> sliced(int d, int pos) const {
1463  Buffer<T, D> im = *this;
1464 
1465  // This guarantees the prexisting device ref is dropped if the
1466  // device_slice call fails and maintains the buffer in a consistent
1467  // state.
1468  im.device_deallocate();
1469 
1470  im.slice_host(d, pos);
1471  if (buf.device_interface != nullptr) {
1472  complete_device_slice(im, d, pos);
1473  }
1474  return im;
1475  }
1476 
1477  /** Make a lower-dimensional buffer that refers to one slice of this
1478  * buffer at the dimension's minimum. */
1479  inline Buffer<T, D> sliced(int d) const {
1480  return sliced(d, dim(d).min());
1481  }
1482 
1483  /** Rewrite the buffer to refer to a single lower-dimensional
1484  * slice of itself along the given dimension at the given
1485  * coordinate. Does not move any data around or free the original
1486  * memory, so other views of the same data are unaffected. */
1487  void slice(int d, int pos) {
1488  // An optimization for non-device buffers. For the device case,
1489  // a temp buffer is required, so reuse the not-in-place version.
1490  // TODO(zalman|abadams): Are nop slices common enough to special
1491  // case the device part of the if to do nothing?
1492  if (buf.device_interface != nullptr) {
1493  *this = sliced(d, pos);
1494  } else {
1495  slice_host(d, pos);
1496  }
1497  }
1498 
1499  /** Slice a buffer in-place at the dimension's minimum. */
1500  inline void slice(int d) {
1501  slice(d, dim(d).min());
1502  }
1503 
1504  /** Make a new buffer that views this buffer as a single slice in a
1505  * higher-dimensional space. The new dimension has extent one and
1506  * the given min. This operation is the opposite of slice. As an
1507  * example, the following condition is true:
1508  *
1509  \code
1510  im2 = im.embedded(1, 17);
1511  &im(x, y, c) == &im2(x, 17, y, c);
1512  \endcode
1513  */
1514  Buffer<T, D> embedded(int d, int pos = 0) const {
1515  Buffer<T, D> im(*this);
1516  im.embed(d, pos);
1517  return im;
1518  }
1519 
1520  /** Embed a buffer in-place, increasing the
1521  * dimensionality. */
1522  void embed(int d, int pos = 0) {
1523  assert(d >= 0 && d <= dimensions());
1524  add_dimension();
1525  translate(dimensions() - 1, pos);
1526  for (int i = dimensions() - 1; i > d; i--) {
1527  transpose(i, i - 1);
1528  }
1529  }
1530 
1531  /** Add a new dimension with a min of zero and an extent of
1532  * one. The stride is the extent of the outermost dimension times
1533  * its stride. The new dimension is the last dimension. This is a
1534  * special case of embed. */
1535  void add_dimension() {
1536  const int dims = buf.dimensions;
1537  buf.dimensions++;
1538  if (buf.dim != shape) {
1539  // We're already on the heap. Reallocate.
1540  halide_dimension_t *new_shape = new halide_dimension_t[buf.dimensions];
1541  for (int i = 0; i < dims; i++) {
1542  new_shape[i] = buf.dim[i];
1543  }
1544  delete[] buf.dim;
1545  buf.dim = new_shape;
1546  } else if (dims == D) {
1547  // Transition from the in-class storage to the heap
1548  make_shape_storage(buf.dimensions);
1549  for (int i = 0; i < dims; i++) {
1550  buf.dim[i] = shape[i];
1551  }
1552  } else {
1553  // We still fit in the class
1554  }
1555  buf.dim[dims] = {0, 1, 0};
1556  if (dims == 0) {
1557  buf.dim[dims].stride = 1;
1558  } else {
1559  buf.dim[dims].stride = buf.dim[dims - 1].extent * buf.dim[dims - 1].stride;
1560  }
1561  }
1562 
1563  /** Add a new dimension with a min of zero, an extent of one, and
1564  * the specified stride. The new dimension is the last
1565  * dimension. This is a special case of embed. */
1566  void add_dimension_with_stride(int s) {
1567  add_dimension();
1568  buf.dim[buf.dimensions - 1].stride = s;
1569  }
1570 
1571  /** Methods for managing any GPU allocation. */
1572  // @{
1573  // Set the host dirty flag. Called by every operator()
1574  // access. Must be inlined so it can be hoisted out of loops.
1575  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1576  void set_host_dirty(bool v = true) {
1577  assert((!v || !device_dirty()) && "Cannot set host dirty when device is already dirty. Call copy_to_host() before accessing the buffer from host.");
1578  buf.set_host_dirty(v);
1579  }
1580 
1581  // Check if the device allocation is dirty. Called by
1582  // set_host_dirty, which is called by every accessor. Must be
1583  // inlined so it can be hoisted out of loops.
1584  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1585  bool device_dirty() const {
1586  return buf.device_dirty();
1587  }
1588 
1589  bool host_dirty() const {
1590  return buf.host_dirty();
1591  }
1592 
1593  void set_device_dirty(bool v = true) {
1594  assert((!v || !host_dirty()) && "Cannot set device dirty when host is already dirty.");
1595  buf.set_device_dirty(v);
1596  }
1597 
1598  int copy_to_host(void *ctx = nullptr) {
1599  if (device_dirty()) {
1600  return buf.device_interface->copy_to_host(ctx, &buf);
1601  }
1602  return 0;
1603  }
1604 
1605  int copy_to_device(const struct halide_device_interface_t *device_interface, void *ctx = nullptr) {
1606  if (host_dirty()) {
1607  return device_interface->copy_to_device(ctx, &buf, device_interface);
1608  }
1609  return 0;
1610  }
1611 
1612  int device_malloc(const struct halide_device_interface_t *device_interface, void *ctx = nullptr) {
1613  return device_interface->device_malloc(ctx, &buf, device_interface);
1614  }
1615 
1616  int device_free(void *ctx = nullptr) {
1617  if (dev_ref_count) {
1618  assert(dev_ref_count->ownership == BufferDeviceOwnership::Allocated &&
1619  "Can't call device_free on an unmanaged or wrapped native device handle. "
1620  "Free the source allocation or call device_detach_native instead.");
1621  // Multiple people may be holding onto this dev field
1622  assert(dev_ref_count->count == 1 &&
1623  "Multiple Halide::Runtime::Buffer objects share this device "
1624  "allocation. Freeing it would create dangling references. "
1625  "Don't call device_free on Halide buffers that you have copied or "
1626  "passed by value.");
1627  }
1628  int ret = 0;
1629  if (buf.device_interface) {
1630  ret = buf.device_interface->device_free(ctx, &buf);
1631  }
1632  if (dev_ref_count) {
1633  delete dev_ref_count;
1634  dev_ref_count = nullptr;
1635  }
1636  return ret;
1637  }
1638 
1639  int device_wrap_native(const struct halide_device_interface_t *device_interface,
1640  uint64_t handle, void *ctx = nullptr) {
1641  assert(device_interface);
1642  dev_ref_count = new DeviceRefCount;
1643  dev_ref_count->ownership = BufferDeviceOwnership::WrappedNative;
1644  return device_interface->wrap_native(ctx, &buf, handle, device_interface);
1645  }
1646 
1647  int device_detach_native(void *ctx = nullptr) {
1648  assert(dev_ref_count &&
1649  dev_ref_count->ownership == BufferDeviceOwnership::WrappedNative &&
1650  "Only call device_detach_native on buffers wrapping a native "
1651  "device handle via device_wrap_native. This buffer was allocated "
1652  "using device_malloc, or is unmanaged. "
1653  "Call device_free or free the original allocation instead.");
1654  // Multiple people may be holding onto this dev field
1655  assert(dev_ref_count->count == 1 &&
1656  "Multiple Halide::Runtime::Buffer objects share this device "
1657  "allocation. Freeing it could create dangling references. "
1658  "Don't call device_detach_native on Halide buffers that you "
1659  "have copied or passed by value.");
1660  int ret = 0;
1661  if (buf.device_interface) {
1662  ret = buf.device_interface->detach_native(ctx, &buf);
1663  }
1664  delete dev_ref_count;
1665  dev_ref_count = nullptr;
1666  return ret;
1667  }
1668 
1669  int device_and_host_malloc(const struct halide_device_interface_t *device_interface, void *ctx = nullptr) {
1670  return device_interface->device_and_host_malloc(ctx, &buf, device_interface);
1671  }
1672 
1673  int device_and_host_free(const struct halide_device_interface_t *device_interface, void *ctx = nullptr) {
1674  if (dev_ref_count) {
1675  assert(dev_ref_count->ownership == BufferDeviceOwnership::AllocatedDeviceAndHost &&
1676  "Can't call device_and_host_free on a device handle not allocated with device_and_host_malloc. "
1677  "Free the source allocation or call device_detach_native instead.");
1678  // Multiple people may be holding onto this dev field
1679  assert(dev_ref_count->count == 1 &&
1680  "Multiple Halide::Runtime::Buffer objects share this device "
1681  "allocation. Freeing it would create dangling references. "
1682  "Don't call device_and_host_free on Halide buffers that you have copied or "
1683  "passed by value.");
1684  }
1685  int ret = 0;
1686  if (buf.device_interface) {
1687  ret = buf.device_interface->device_and_host_free(ctx, &buf);
1688  }
1689  if (dev_ref_count) {
1690  delete dev_ref_count;
1691  dev_ref_count = nullptr;
1692  }
1693  return ret;
1694  }
1695 
1696  int device_sync(void *ctx = nullptr) {
1697  if (buf.device_interface) {
1698  return buf.device_interface->device_sync(ctx, &buf);
1699  } else {
1700  return 0;
1701  }
1702  }
1703 
1704  bool has_device_allocation() const {
1705  return buf.device != 0;
1706  }
1707 
1708  /** Return the method by which the device field is managed. */
1709  BufferDeviceOwnership device_ownership() const {
1710  if (dev_ref_count == nullptr) {
1711  return BufferDeviceOwnership::Allocated;
1712  }
1713  return dev_ref_count->ownership;
1714  }
1715  // @}
1716 
1717  /** If you use the (x, y, c) indexing convention, then Halide
1718  * Buffers are stored planar by default. This function constructs
1719  * an interleaved RGB or RGBA image that can still be indexed
1720  * using (x, y, c). Passing it to a generator requires that the
1721  * generator has been compiled with support for interleaved (also
1722  * known as packed or chunky) memory layouts. */
1723  static Buffer<void, D> make_interleaved(halide_type_t t, int width, int height, int channels) {
1724  Buffer<void, D> im(t, channels, width, height);
1725  // Note that this is equivalent to calling transpose({2, 0, 1}),
1726  // but slightly more efficient.
1727  im.transpose(0, 1);
1728  im.transpose(1, 2);
1729  return im;
1730  }
1731 
1732  /** If you use the (x, y, c) indexing convention, then Halide
1733  * Buffers are stored planar by default. This function constructs
1734  * an interleaved RGB or RGBA image that can still be indexed
1735  * using (x, y, c). Passing it to a generator requires that the
1736  * generator has been compiled with support for interleaved (also
1737  * known as packed or chunky) memory layouts. */
1738  static Buffer<T, D> make_interleaved(int width, int height, int channels) {
1739  return make_interleaved(static_halide_type(), width, height, channels);
1740  }
1741 
1742  /** Wrap an existing interleaved image. */
1743  static Buffer<add_const_if_T_is_const<void>, D>
1744  make_interleaved(halide_type_t t, T *data, int width, int height, int channels) {
1745  Buffer<add_const_if_T_is_const<void>, D> im(t, data, channels, width, height);
1746  im.transpose(0, 1);
1747  im.transpose(1, 2);
1748  return im;
1749  }
1750 
1751  /** Wrap an existing interleaved image. */
1752  static Buffer<T, D> make_interleaved(T *data, int width, int height, int channels) {
1753  return make_interleaved(static_halide_type(), data, width, height, channels);
1754  }
1755 
1756  /** Make a zero-dimensional Buffer */
1757  static Buffer<add_const_if_T_is_const<void>, D> make_scalar(halide_type_t t) {
1758  Buffer<add_const_if_T_is_const<void>, 1> buf(t, 1);
1759  buf.slice(0, 0);
1760  return buf;
1761  }
1762 
1763  /** Make a zero-dimensional Buffer */
1764  static Buffer<T, D> make_scalar() {
1765  Buffer<T, 1> buf(1);
1766  buf.slice(0, 0);
1767  return buf;
1768  }
1769 
1770  /** Make a zero-dimensional Buffer that points to non-owned, existing data */
1771  static Buffer<T, D> make_scalar(T *data) {
1772  Buffer<T, 1> buf(data, 1);
1773  buf.slice(0, 0);
1774  return buf;
1775  }
1776 
1777  /** Make a buffer with the same shape and memory nesting order as
1778  * another buffer. It may have a different type. */
1779  template<typename T2, int D2>
1780  static Buffer<T, D> make_with_shape_of(Buffer<T2, D2> src,
1781  void *(*allocate_fn)(size_t) = nullptr,
1782  void (*deallocate_fn)(void *) = nullptr) {
1783 
1784  const halide_type_t dst_type = T_is_void ? src.type() : halide_type_of<typename std::remove_cv<not_void_T>::type>();
1785  return Buffer<>::make_with_shape_of_helper(dst_type, src.dimensions(), src.buf.dim,
1786  allocate_fn, deallocate_fn);
1787  }
1788 
1789 private:
1790  static Buffer<> make_with_shape_of_helper(halide_type_t dst_type,
1791  int dimensions,
1792  halide_dimension_t *shape,
1793  void *(*allocate_fn)(size_t),
1794  void (*deallocate_fn)(void *)) {
1795  // Reorder the dimensions of src to have strides in increasing order
1796  std::vector<int> swaps;
1797  for (int i = dimensions - 1; i > 0; i--) {
1798  for (int j = i; j > 0; j--) {
1799  if (shape[j - 1].stride > shape[j].stride) {
1800  std::swap(shape[j - 1], shape[j]);
1801  swaps.push_back(j);
1802  }
1803  }
1804  }
1805 
1806  // Rewrite the strides to be dense (this messes up src, which
1807  // is why we took it by value).
1808  for (int i = 0; i < dimensions; i++) {
1809  if (i == 0) {
1810  shape[i].stride = 1;
1811  } else {
1812  shape[i].stride = shape[i - 1].extent * shape[i - 1].stride;
1813  }
1814  }
1815 
1816  // Undo the dimension reordering
1817  while (!swaps.empty()) {
1818  int j = swaps.back();
1819  std::swap(shape[j - 1], shape[j]);
1820  swaps.pop_back();
1821  }
1822 
1823  // Use an explicit runtime type, and make dst a Buffer<void>, to allow
1824  // using this method with Buffer<void> for either src or dst.
1825  Buffer<> dst(dst_type, nullptr, dimensions, shape);
1826  dst.allocate(allocate_fn, deallocate_fn);
1827 
1828  return dst;
1829  }
1830 
1831  template<typename... Args>
1832  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1833  ptrdiff_t
1834  offset_of(int d, int first, Args... rest) const {
1835  return offset_of(d + 1, rest...) + (ptrdiff_t)this->buf.dim[d].stride * (first - this->buf.dim[d].min);
1836  }
1837 
1838  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1839  ptrdiff_t offset_of(int d) const {
1840  return 0;
1841  }
1842 
1843  template<typename... Args>
1844  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1845  storage_T *
1846  address_of(Args... args) const {
1847  if (T_is_void) {
1848  return (storage_T *)(this->buf.host) + offset_of(0, args...) * type().bytes();
1849  } else {
1850  return (storage_T *)(this->buf.host) + offset_of(0, args...);
1851  }
1852  }
1853 
1854  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1855  ptrdiff_t offset_of(const int *pos) const {
1856  ptrdiff_t offset = 0;
1857  for (int i = this->dimensions() - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
1858  offset += (ptrdiff_t)this->buf.dim[i].stride * (pos[i] - this->buf.dim[i].min);
1859  }
1860  return offset;
1861  }
1862 
1863  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1864  storage_T *address_of(const int *pos) const {
1865  if (T_is_void) {
1866  return (storage_T *)this->buf.host + offset_of(pos) * type().bytes();
1867  } else {
1868  return (storage_T *)this->buf.host + offset_of(pos);
1869  }
1870  }
1871 
1872 public:
1873  /** Get a pointer to the address of the min coordinate. */
1874  T *data() const {
1875  return (T *)(this->buf.host);
1876  }
1877 
1878  /** Access elements. Use im(...) to get a reference to an element,
1879  * and use &im(...) to get the address of an element. If you pass
1880  * fewer arguments than the buffer has dimensions, the rest are
1881  * treated as their min coordinate. The non-const versions set the
1882  * host_dirty flag to true.
1883  */
1884  //@{
1885  template<typename... Args,
1886  typename = typename std::enable_if<AllInts<Args...>::value>::type>
1887  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE const not_void_T &operator()(int first, Args... rest) const {
1888  static_assert(!T_is_void,
1889  "Cannot use operator() on Buffer<void> types");
1890  assert(!device_dirty());
1891  return *((const not_void_T *)(address_of(first, rest...)));
1892  }
1893 
1894  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1895  const not_void_T &
1896  operator()() const {
1897  static_assert(!T_is_void,
1898  "Cannot use operator() on Buffer<void> types");
1899  assert(!device_dirty());
1900  return *((const not_void_T *)(data()));
1901  }
1902 
1903  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1904  const not_void_T &
1905  operator()(const int *pos) const {
1906  static_assert(!T_is_void,
1907  "Cannot use operator() on Buffer<void> types");
1908  assert(!device_dirty());
1909  return *((const not_void_T *)(address_of(pos)));
1910  }
1911 
1912  template<typename... Args,
1913  typename = typename std::enable_if<AllInts<Args...>::value>::type>
1914  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1915  not_void_T &
1916  operator()(int first, Args... rest) {
1917  static_assert(!T_is_void,
1918  "Cannot use operator() on Buffer<void> types");
1919  set_host_dirty();
1920  return *((not_void_T *)(address_of(first, rest...)));
1921  }
1922 
1923  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1924  not_void_T &
1925  operator()() {
1926  static_assert(!T_is_void,
1927  "Cannot use operator() on Buffer<void> types");
1928  set_host_dirty();
1929  return *((not_void_T *)(data()));
1930  }
1931 
1932  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1933  not_void_T &
1934  operator()(const int *pos) {
1935  static_assert(!T_is_void,
1936  "Cannot use operator() on Buffer<void> types");
1937  set_host_dirty();
1938  return *((not_void_T *)(address_of(pos)));
1939  }
1940  // @}
1941 
1942  /** Tests that all values in this buffer are equal to val. */
1943  bool all_equal(not_void_T val) const {
1944  bool all_equal = true;
1945  for_each_element([&](const int *pos) { all_equal &= (*this)(pos) == val; });
1946  return all_equal;
1947  }
1948 
1949  Buffer<T, D> &fill(not_void_T val) {
1950  set_host_dirty();
1951  for_each_value([=](T &v) { v = val; });
1952  return *this;
1953  }
1954 
1955 private:
1956  /** Helper functions for for_each_value. */
1957  // @{
1958  template<int N>
1959  struct for_each_value_task_dim {
1960  int extent;
1961  int stride[N];
1962  };
1963 
1964  // Given an array of strides, and a bunch of pointers to pointers
1965  // (all of different types), advance the pointers using the
1966  // strides.
1967  template<typename Ptr, typename... Ptrs>
1968  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static void advance_ptrs(const int *stride, Ptr *ptr, Ptrs... ptrs) {
1969  (*ptr) += *stride;
1970  advance_ptrs(stride + 1, ptrs...);
1971  }
1972 
1973  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1974  static void advance_ptrs(const int *) {
1975  }
1976 
1977  // Same as the above, but just increments the pointers.
1978  template<typename Ptr, typename... Ptrs>
1979  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static void increment_ptrs(Ptr *ptr, Ptrs... ptrs) {
1980  (*ptr)++;
1981  increment_ptrs(ptrs...);
1982  }
1983 
1984  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
1985  static void increment_ptrs() {
1986  }
1987 
1988  template<typename Fn, typename... Ptrs>
1989  HALIDE_NEVER_INLINE static void for_each_value_helper(Fn &&f, int d, bool innermost_strides_are_one,
1990  const for_each_value_task_dim<sizeof...(Ptrs)> *t, Ptrs... ptrs) {
1991  if (d == -1) {
1992  f((*ptrs)...);
1993  } else if (d == 0) {
1994  if (innermost_strides_are_one) {
1995  for (int i = t[0].extent; i != 0; i--) {
1996  f((*ptrs)...);
1997  increment_ptrs((&ptrs)...);
1998  }
1999  } else {
2000  for (int i = t[0].extent; i != 0; i--) {
2001  f((*ptrs)...);
2002  advance_ptrs(t[0].stride, (&ptrs)...);
2003  }
2004  }
2005  } else {
2006  for (int i = t[d].extent; i != 0; i--) {
2007  for_each_value_helper(f, d - 1, innermost_strides_are_one, t, ptrs...);
2008  advance_ptrs(t[d].stride, (&ptrs)...);
2009  }
2010  }
2011  }
2012 
2013  template<int N>
2014  HALIDE_NEVER_INLINE static bool for_each_value_prep(for_each_value_task_dim<N> *t,
2015  const halide_buffer_t **buffers) {
2016  // Check the buffers all have clean host allocations
2017  for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
2018  if (buffers[i]->device) {
2019  assert(buffers[i]->host &&
2020  "Buffer passed to for_each_value has device allocation but no host allocation. Call allocate() and copy_to_host() first");
2021  assert(!buffers[i]->device_dirty() &&
2022  "Buffer passed to for_each_value is dirty on device. Call copy_to_host() first");
2023  } else {
2024  assert(buffers[i]->host &&
2025  "Buffer passed to for_each_value has no host or device allocation");
2026  }
2027  }
2028 
2029  const int dimensions = buffers[0]->dimensions;
2030 
2031  // Extract the strides in all the dimensions
2032  for (int i = 0; i < dimensions; i++) {
2033  for (int j = 0; j < N; j++) {
2034  assert(buffers[j]->dimensions == dimensions);
2035  assert(buffers[j]->dim[i].extent == buffers[0]->dim[i].extent &&
2036  buffers[j]->dim[i].min == buffers[0]->dim[i].min);
2037  const int s = buffers[j]->dim[i].stride;
2038  t[i].stride[j] = s;
2039  }
2040  t[i].extent = buffers[0]->dim[i].extent;
2041 
2042  // Order the dimensions by stride, so that the traversal is cache-coherent.
2043  for (int j = i; j > 0 && t[j].stride[0] < t[j - 1].stride[0]; j--) {
2044  std::swap(t[j], t[j - 1]);
2045  }
2046  }
2047 
2048  // flatten dimensions where possible to make a larger inner
2049  // loop for autovectorization.
2050  int d = dimensions;
2051  for (int i = 1; i < d; i++) {
2052  bool flat = true;
2053  for (int j = 0; j < N; j++) {
2054  flat = flat && t[i - 1].stride[j] * t[i - 1].extent == t[i].stride[j];
2055  }
2056  if (flat) {
2057  t[i - 1].extent *= t[i].extent;
2058  for (int j = i; j < d; j++) {
2059  t[j] = t[j + 1];
2060  }
2061  i--;
2062  d--;
2063  t[d].extent = 1;
2064  }
2065  }
2066 
2067  bool innermost_strides_are_one = true;
2068  if (dimensions > 0) {
2069  for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
2070  innermost_strides_are_one &= (t[0].stride[i] == 1);
2071  }
2072  }
2073 
2074  return innermost_strides_are_one;
2075  }
2076 
2077  template<typename Fn, typename... Args, int N = sizeof...(Args) + 1>
2078  void for_each_value_impl(Fn &&f, Args &&...other_buffers) const {
2079  Buffer<>::for_each_value_task_dim<N> *t =
2080  (Buffer<>::for_each_value_task_dim<N> *)HALIDE_ALLOCA((dimensions() + 1) * sizeof(for_each_value_task_dim<N>));
2081  // Move the preparatory code into a non-templated helper to
2082  // save code size.
2083  const halide_buffer_t *buffers[] = {&buf, (&other_buffers.buf)...};
2084  bool innermost_strides_are_one = Buffer<>::for_each_value_prep(t, buffers);
2085 
2086  Buffer<>::for_each_value_helper(f, dimensions() - 1,
2087  innermost_strides_are_one,
2088  t,
2089  data(), (other_buffers.data())...);
2090  }
2091  // @}
2092 
2093 public:
2094  /** Call a function on every value in the buffer, and the
2095  * corresponding values in some number of other buffers of the
2096  * same size. The function should take a reference, const
2097  * reference, or value of the correct type for each buffer. This
2098  * effectively lifts a function of scalars to an element-wise
2099  * function of buffers. This produces code that the compiler can
2100  * autovectorize. This is slightly cheaper than for_each_element,
2101  * because it does not need to track the coordinates.
2102  *
2103  * Note that constness of Buffers is preserved: a const Buffer<T> (for either
2104  * 'this' or the other-buffers arguments) will allow mutation of the
2105  * buffer contents, while a Buffer<const T> will not. Attempting to specify
2106  * a mutable reference for the lambda argument of a Buffer<const T>
2107  * will result in a compilation error. */
2108  // @{
2109  template<typename Fn, typename... Args, int N = sizeof...(Args) + 1>
2110  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE const Buffer<T, D> &for_each_value(Fn &&f, Args &&...other_buffers) const {
2111  for_each_value_impl(f, std::forward<Args>(other_buffers)...);
2112  return *this;
2113  }
2114 
2115  template<typename Fn, typename... Args, int N = sizeof...(Args) + 1>
2116  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
2117  Buffer<T, D> &
2118  for_each_value(Fn &&f, Args &&...other_buffers) {
2119  for_each_value_impl(f, std::forward<Args>(other_buffers)...);
2120  return *this;
2121  }
2122  // @}
2123 
2124 private:
2125  // Helper functions for for_each_element
2126  struct for_each_element_task_dim {
2127  int min, max;
2128  };
2129 
2130  /** If f is callable with this many args, call it. The first
2131  * argument is just to make the overloads distinct. Actual
2132  * overload selection is done using the enable_if. */
2133  template<typename Fn,
2134  typename... Args,
2135  typename = decltype(std::declval<Fn>()(std::declval<Args>()...))>
2136  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static void for_each_element_variadic(int, int, const for_each_element_task_dim *, Fn &&f, Args... args) {
2137  f(args...);
2138  }
2139 
2140  /** If the above overload is impossible, we add an outer loop over
2141  * an additional argument and try again. */
2142  template<typename Fn,
2143  typename... Args>
2144  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static void for_each_element_variadic(double, int d, const for_each_element_task_dim *t, Fn &&f, Args... args) {
2145  for (int i = t[d].min; i <= t[d].max; i++) {
2146  for_each_element_variadic(0, d - 1, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), i, args...);
2147  }
2148  }
2149 
2150  /** Determine the minimum number of arguments a callable can take
2151  * using the same trick. */
2152  template<typename Fn,
2153  typename... Args,
2154  typename = decltype(std::declval<Fn>()(std::declval<Args>()...))>
2155  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static int num_args(int, Fn &&, Args...) {
2156  return (int)(sizeof...(Args));
2157  }
2158 
2159  /** The recursive version is only enabled up to a recursion limit
2160  * of 256. This catches callables that aren't callable with any
2161  * number of ints. */
2162  template<typename Fn,
2163  typename... Args>
2164  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static int num_args(double, Fn &&f, Args... args) {
2165  static_assert(sizeof...(args) <= 256,
2166  "Callable passed to for_each_element must accept either a const int *,"
2167  " or up to 256 ints. No such operator found. Expect infinite template recursion.");
2168  return num_args(0, std::forward<Fn>(f), 0, args...);
2169  }
2170 
2171  /** A version where the callable takes a position array instead,
2172  * with compile-time recursion on the dimensionality. This
2173  * overload is preferred to the one below using the same int vs
2174  * double trick as above, but is impossible once d hits -1 using
2175  * std::enable_if. */
2176  template<int d,
2177  typename Fn,
2178  typename = typename std::enable_if<(d >= 0)>::type>
2179  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static void for_each_element_array_helper(int, const for_each_element_task_dim *t, Fn &&f, int *pos) {
2180  for (pos[d] = t[d].min; pos[d] <= t[d].max; pos[d]++) {
2181  for_each_element_array_helper<d - 1>(0, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), pos);
2182  }
2183  }
2184 
2185  /** Base case for recursion above. */
2186  template<int d,
2187  typename Fn,
2188  typename = typename std::enable_if<(d < 0)>::type>
2189  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static void for_each_element_array_helper(double, const for_each_element_task_dim *t, Fn &&f, int *pos) {
2190  f(pos);
2191  }
2192 
2193  /** A run-time-recursive version (instead of
2194  * compile-time-recursive) that requires the callable to take a
2195  * pointer to a position array instead. Dispatches to the
2196  * compile-time-recursive version once the dimensionality gets
2197  * small. */
2198  template<typename Fn>
2199  static void for_each_element_array(int d, const for_each_element_task_dim *t, Fn &&f, int *pos) {
2200  if (d == -1) {
2201  f(pos);
2202  } else if (d == 0) {
2203  // Once the dimensionality gets small enough, dispatch to
2204  // a compile-time-recursive version for better codegen of
2205  // the inner loops.
2206  for_each_element_array_helper<0, Fn>(0, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), pos);
2207  } else if (d == 1) {
2208  for_each_element_array_helper<1, Fn>(0, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), pos);
2209  } else if (d == 2) {
2210  for_each_element_array_helper<2, Fn>(0, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), pos);
2211  } else if (d == 3) {
2212  for_each_element_array_helper<3, Fn>(0, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), pos);
2213  } else {
2214  for (pos[d] = t[d].min; pos[d] <= t[d].max; pos[d]++) {
2215  for_each_element_array(d - 1, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), pos);
2216  }
2217  }
2218  }
2219 
2220  /** We now have two overloads for for_each_element. This one
2221  * triggers if the callable takes a const int *.
2222  */
2223  template<typename Fn,
2224  typename = decltype(std::declval<Fn>()((const int *)nullptr))>
2225  static void for_each_element(int, int dims, const for_each_element_task_dim *t, Fn &&f, int check = 0) {
2226  int *pos = (int *)HALIDE_ALLOCA(dims * sizeof(int));
2227  for_each_element_array(dims - 1, t, std::forward<Fn>(f), pos);
2228  }
2229 
2230  /** This one triggers otherwise. It treats the callable as
2231  * something that takes some number of ints. */
2232  template<typename Fn>
2233  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE static void for_each_element(double, int dims, const for_each_element_task_dim *t, Fn &&f) {
2234  int args = num_args(0, std::forward<Fn>(f));
2235  assert(dims >= args);
2236  for_each_element_variadic(0, args - 1, t, std::forward<Fn>(f));
2237  }
2238 
2239  template<typename Fn>
2240  void for_each_element_impl(Fn &&f) const {
2241  for_each_element_task_dim *t =
2242  (for_each_element_task_dim *)HALIDE_ALLOCA(dimensions() * sizeof(for_each_element_task_dim));
2243  for (int i = 0; i < dimensions(); i++) {
2244  t[i].min = dim(i).min();
2245  t[i].max = dim(i).max();
2246  }
2247  for_each_element(0, dimensions(), t, std::forward<Fn>(f));
2248  }
2249 
2250 public:
2251  /** Call a function at each site in a buffer. This is likely to be
2252  * much slower than using Halide code to populate a buffer, but is
2253  * convenient for tests. If the function has more arguments than the
2254  * buffer has dimensions, the remaining arguments will be zero. If it
2255  * has fewer arguments than the buffer has dimensions then the last
2256  * few dimensions of the buffer are not iterated over. For example,
2257  * the following code exploits this to set a floating point RGB image
2258  * to red:
2259 
2260  \code
2261  Buffer<float, 3> im(100, 100, 3);
2262  im.for_each_element([&](int x, int y) {
2263  im(x, y, 0) = 1.0f;
2264  im(x, y, 1) = 0.0f;
2265  im(x, y, 2) = 0.0f:
2266  });
2267  \endcode
2268 
2269  * The compiled code is equivalent to writing the a nested for loop,
2270  * and compilers are capable of optimizing it in the same way.
2271  *
2272  * If the callable can be called with an int * as the sole argument,
2273  * that version is called instead. Each location in the buffer is
2274  * passed to it in a coordinate array. This version is higher-overhead
2275  * than the variadic version, but is useful for writing generic code
2276  * that accepts buffers of arbitrary dimensionality. For example, the
2277  * following sets the value at all sites in an arbitrary-dimensional
2278  * buffer to their first coordinate:
2279 
2280  \code
2281  im.for_each_element([&](const int *pos) {im(pos) = pos[0];});
2282  \endcode
2283 
2284  * It is also possible to use for_each_element to iterate over entire
2285  * rows or columns by cropping the buffer to a single column or row
2286  * respectively and iterating over elements of the result. For example,
2287  * to set the diagonal of the image to 1 by iterating over the columns:
2288 
2289  \code
2290  Buffer<float, 3> im(100, 100, 3);
2291  im.sliced(1, 0).for_each_element([&](int x, int c) {
2292  im(x, x, c) = 1.0f;
2293  });
2294  \endcode
2295 
2296  * Or, assuming the memory layout is known to be dense per row, one can
2297  * memset each row of an image like so:
2298 
2299  \code
2300  Buffer<float, 3> im(100, 100, 3);
2301  im.sliced(0, 0).for_each_element([&](int y, int c) {
2302  memset(&im(0, y, c), 0, sizeof(float) * im.width());
2303  });
2304  \endcode
2305 
2306  */
2307  // @{
2308  template<typename Fn>
2309  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE const Buffer<T, D> &for_each_element(Fn &&f) const {
2310  for_each_element_impl(f);
2311  return *this;
2312  }
2313 
2314  template<typename Fn>
2315  HALIDE_ALWAYS_INLINE
2316  Buffer<T, D> &
2317  for_each_element(Fn &&f) {
2318  for_each_element_impl(f);
2319  return *this;
2320  }
2321  // @}
2322 
2323 private:
2324  template<typename Fn>
2325  struct FillHelper {
2326  Fn f;
2327  Buffer<T, D> *buf;
2328 
2329  template<typename... Args,
2330  typename = decltype(std::declval<Fn>()(std::declval<Args>()...))>
2331  void operator()(Args... args) {
2332  (*buf)(args...) = f(args...);
2333  }
2334 
2335  FillHelper(Fn &&f, Buffer<T, D> *buf)
2336  : f(std::forward<Fn>(f)), buf(buf) {
2337  }
2338  };
2339 
2340 public:
2341  /** Fill a buffer by evaluating a callable at every site. The
2342  * callable should look much like a callable passed to
2343  * for_each_element, but it should return the value that should be
2344  * stored to the coordinate corresponding to the arguments. */
2345  template<typename Fn,
2346  typename = typename std::enable_if<!std::is_arithmetic<typename std::decay<Fn>::type>::value>::type>
2347  Buffer<T, D> &fill(Fn &&f) {
2348  // We'll go via for_each_element. We need a variadic wrapper lambda.
2349  FillHelper<Fn> wrapper(std::forward<Fn>(f), this);
2350  return for_each_element(wrapper);
2351  }
2352 
2353  /** Check if an input buffer passed extern stage is a querying
2354  * bounds. Compared to doing the host pointer check directly,
2355  * this both adds clarity to code and will facilitate moving to
2356  * another representation for bounds query arguments. */
2357  bool is_bounds_query() const {
2358  return buf.is_bounds_query();
2359  }
2360 
2361  /** Convenient check to verify that all of the interesting bytes in the Buffer
2362  * are initialized under MSAN. Note that by default, we use for_each_value() here so that
2363  * we skip any unused padding that isn't part of the Buffer; this isn't efficient,
2364  * but in MSAN mode, it doesn't matter. (Pass true for the flag to force check
2365  * the entire Buffer storage.) */
2366  void msan_check_mem_is_initialized(bool entire = false) const {
2367 #if defined(__has_feature)
2368 #if __has_feature(memory_sanitizer)
2369  if (entire) {
2370  __msan_check_mem_is_initialized(data(), size_in_bytes());
2371  } else {
2372  for_each_value([](T &v) { __msan_check_mem_is_initialized(&v, sizeof(T)); ; });
2373  }
2374 #endif
2375 #endif
2376  }
2377 };
2378 
2379 } // namespace Runtime
2380 } // namespace Halide
2381 
2382 #undef HALIDE_ALLOCA
2383 
2384 #endif // HALIDE_RUNTIME_IMAGE_H

Halide::Runtime::BufferDeviceOwnership::Allocated

Halide::Runtime::BufferDeviceOwnership::AllocatedDeviceAndHost
@ AllocatedDeviceAndHost

Halide::Runtime::BufferDeviceOwnership::WrappedNative
@ WrappedNative

@ Cropped
